139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:22): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: would it be fair to say you think technical purity is quite important when it comes to markup and protocols?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:22): Maciej, is that a trick question?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:23): Yes, I think technical purity is a good thing. But of course there are other things to consider as well.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:23): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: it seems to be a much lower priority for you when it comes to the DOM
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:23): I'm puzzled by the disconnect
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:23): Right now I think that many people think of technical purity as something bad, and are more than happy to ignore it without sufficient reason.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:24): DOM in itself is inconsistent, because it allows mixing L1 and L2 access.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:25): That IE doesn't support L2 makes things even harder.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:25): So I think it would be very interesting to discuss a new API that doesn't repeat those mistakes.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:25): does that mean it's ok to design specs so that L1 access will let you pass the test cases, but L2 access won't, even in DOMs that support Level 2?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:25): But it's probably too late to do that for HTML5.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:26): (for namespace-aware content)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:26): (er, for namespaced content rather)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:27): If there are RDfa test cases for XHTML which can't be passed by an implementation using pure DOM Level 2, that sounds like a bug.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:27): there are such RDFa test cases for HTML
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:29): e4x tried to be the new and great API

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:29): I don't know if that shows misunderstanding or deliberate violation of the conceptual model, but I think it's one or the other, and I don't think you can blame it on DOM
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (13:30): points out there are tree models that don't give something like nodeName, and you're stuck if you want the actual prefix
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (13:31): Please point to these test cases, optimally in email.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:36): here is one example: http://rdfa.digitalbazaar.com/test-suite/test-cases/html4/0001.html
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (13:36): Title: Test 0001 (at rdfa.digitalbazaar.com)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:37): but I think it's true of all the text/html test cases
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (13:43): planet: XML on the Web <http://www.brucelawson.co.uk/2009/xml-on-the-web/>

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:44): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: Maybe not quite all - you could do <div property="xml:foo"> and it might or might not (I don't think it's been decided by the RDFa group yet) give you a triple, without having to parse any attribute names containing colons
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:45): but that's a bit of an edge case :-p

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:45): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: hmm... the RDFa spec does not seem to make any allowance for the xmlns: or xml: prefixes to be predefined as currently written
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:46): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: but if they were set to be predefined to their usual values for CURIE resolution purposes, then sure

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:46): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: I guess a test case that did not use xmlns: at all and just use ":foo" style CURIEs using the default prefix, that would also work fine with DOM L2 APIs only
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:47): Shane proposed an errate to say that RDFa processors MAY predefine xml and xmlns
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:47): but I think it was generally agreed that that might not be such a good idea
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:48): although if the prefixes aren't defined by default, it's apparently impossible to implement an RDFa processor using XSLT
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:48): I can't really think of legitimate use cases for using the XML or XMLNS namespaces as CURIE prefixes
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:50): It doesn't seem very useful in practice, I just think it's an edge case that ought to be defined
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (13:50): (because I think everything ought to be defined)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): it sucks, though, if you are working with a non-DOM API that has a built-in prefix resolution facility that is sane per namespace but you can't use it because it predefines xml and xmlns
